Q7-breaking_wave_height.name: Q1
Q7-breaking_wave_height.question: Can the wave height at breaking be smaller than the deep water wave height? Use physical reasoning to get to your answer and then verify it from the table.

options.a: No, since there will always be shoaling

feedback.correct: Correct. This happens when refraction becomes increasingly important reducing the wave heights.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Have a look at the table and check the breaking wave height for different φ₀. What is(are) the physical processes that determine the wave height at breaking

Q7-parameters_monotonically_decrease.name: Q2
Q7-parameters_monotonically_decrease.question: For which parameter(s) do the values monotonically decrease if the deep water wave angle increases from 0° to 90°? Verify your answer from the table and try to understand why.

feedback.correct: Correct. Note that φb first increases and then decreases. Can you explain this from Snell's law?
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Verify your answer from the table.

Q7-variation_ub.name: Q3
Q7-variation_ub.question: What is the approximate range of variation of φb?

feedback.correct: Correct. The angle of incidence at breaking is approximately in the range -20° to -20° due to refraction.

Q7-angle_max_transport.name: Q4
Q7-angle_max_transport.question: In our computation, for what deep water angle of incidence φ₀ (in °) is the transport maximum? Give your answer in three significant figures and as a positive angle.

feedback.correct: Correct. The maximum transport is found for a value slightly smaller than 45° (in our computation 42.6°).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Use the cell that computes S for a single wave angle and try multiple wave angles, using sufficient accuracy, around the value for which the maximum is to be expected.

Q7-symmetrical_transport.name: Q5
Q7-symmetrical_transport.question: The transport is not symmetrical around 45°; not only is the maximum shifted but we can also see, for instance, that the transport for a deep water angle of 20° is slightly larger than for 70°. Because of which parameter in Equation 8.10 do we obtain this slight asymmetry?

feedback.correct: Correct. It is due to the decrease of cb with φ₀.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Check Equation 8.10. Which parameters play a role?

Q7-CERC_grain-size.name: Q6
Q7-CERC_grain-size.question: According to the CERC formula, what happens to the transport if the grain-size increases?

feedback.correct: Correct. The grain-size is not found in Equation 8.10. This can be seen as a shortcoming of the formula.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Check Equation 8.10. Which parameters play a role? Do you see the grain-size?

Q7-transport_errr_angle.name: Q7
Q7-transport_errr_angle.question: What is the relative error in S for a deep water angle of incidence of 10°, if one would approximate sin(2φ₀) by 2φ₀? Give your answer as a positive percentage with one significant figure.

feedback.correct: Correct. For small wave angles we can use this approximation.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Compute the relative error using the values in the table as (absolute error)/(true value)*100%

Q7-increase_alongshore_transport.name: Q8
Q7-increase_alongshore_transport.question: Which circumstances would always lead to an increase of the alongshore transport S?

options.e: Angle of incidence increases from 20° to 80°

feedback.correct: Correct. Can you explain why porosity is part of the CERC formula? You have probably found that the effect of the wave period is not very large. It is also difficult to predict in absolute terms; it can either go up or down (try T in the range of 5 to 12 s and see what happens to the different parameters).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Verify the effect of all variables from the CERC equation and the code. For the period you may have to try quite a range of values (try T in the range of 5 to 12 s).

Q7-breaking_wave_height2.name: Notused
Q7-breaking_wave_height2.question: Rerun the code for an offshore wave height of 0.5 m (still with a period of 7 s and an incident angle of 5°). What is the new predicted wave height at breaking (in meters)? Give your answer with two significant figures.

Q7-breaking_wave_transport.name: Notused
Q7-breaking_wave_transport.question: And for this same wave height of 0.5 m, what is the value for the transport S [m3/s]? Either compute your answer, or read it from the plot. Give your answer with two significant figures.

Q7-accretion_length_and_ROI.name: Q9
Q7-accretion_length_and_ROI.question: How do the accretion length L and region of influence X vary with time? They are proportional with:

feedback.correct: Correct. You can see this from the  √t in Equation 8.25.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Check this in the plot of L(t) and X(t). Also verify this from Equation 8.25 and Figure 8.2.

Q7-outward_growth.name: Q10
Q7-outward_growth.question: After how many years is the outward growth of the shoreline at the breakwater equal to 150 m?

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Check this in the plot of L(t).

Q7-angle_at_breakwater.name: Q11
Q7-angle_at_breakwater.question: The angle of the coastline right at the breakwater seems constant throughout the years. Determine this angle. Give your answer as a positive number with two significant figures.

feedback.correct: Correct. For this coastline rotation the waves are effectively normally incident, leading to the zero transport imposed by the breakwater.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. You can estimate it from the figure and verify it from the boundary condition at the breakwater. How large should the local angle of incidence be to satisfy the boundary condition of S = 0 at the breakwater? What does this mean for the shoreline rotation?

Q7-yearly_transport.name: Q12
Q7-yearly_transport.question: How large is the yearly transport (m³/year) in the region where the coastline orientation has not changed yet. Hint: we have seen this value before! Give your answer with (at least) 4 significant figures.

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Check the computation of S aboven

Q7-depth_of_closure.name: Q13
Q7-depth_of_closure.question: Imagine the depth of closure (DOC) is 9 m instead of 7 m. What would change with respect to the evolution of the coastal morphology?

options.a: The shoreline angle close to the breakwater will increase.
options.b: The accretion will extend further updrift.
options.c: The accretion will reach the tip of the breakwater faster.
options.d: The accretion shape will look similar but will develop slower.

feedback.correct: Correct. The development will slow down and after some time the outward growth L and the region of influence X are smaller. This makes sense since a larger part of the profile follows the coastline changes and, hence, larger volumes are involved.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Hint: have a look at Equation 8.16. What happens to dY/dt?. Also look at the role of d in the analytical equations for the outward growth L and the region of influence X.

Q7-shadow_effects.name: Q14
Q7-shadow_effects.question: Say we want to include waves from other directions also, including wave directions for which the breakwater introduces shadow effects. How could we mimick shadow effects in our numerical model? Select the appropriate strategies from the options below.

options.a: Reduce wave height for part of the grid depending on the angle of incidence
options.b: Increase depth of closure close to the breakwater
options.c: Manually decrease transport values close to the breakwater irrespective of the angle of incidence
options.d: Reduce wave height for the entire grid

feedback.correct: Correct. The sheltering of waves is dependent on whether or not the waves can reach the zone near the breakwater and, hence, on the angle of incidence
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. What do we have to reduce? And for which wave angles?

Q7-bypass_effect.name: Q15
Q7-bypass_effect.question: Say we want to include bypass effects in our numerical model, e.g. when the accretion reaches the tip of the breakwater. Select the appropriate strategies from the options below.

options.a: Use a conditional boundary condition which changes after accretion at the breakwater has reached a certain length
options.b: Mirror the updrift solution and use that as a downdrift solution
options.c: Implicitly include bypass effects by including shadow zone effects
options.d: Calculate the transport twice (with and without breakwater), and use the average value for transport at the breakwater

feedback.correct: Correct. The transport at the breakwater is zero until bypass and becomes non-zero after bypass.

Q7-yearly_transport2.name: Q16
Q7-yearly_transport2.question: What is the yearly transport for the initial or reference coastline orientation? Give your answer with (at least) 3 significant figures.

feedback.correct: Correct. You can read this transport from the plot as well as compute it from the provided cell.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. What is the coastline orientation that you should use? Read the corresponding transport from the plot as well as compute it from the provided cell.

Q7-angle_zero_transport.name: Q17
Q7-angle_zero_transport.question: What is the angle over which the coast has to rotate for the transport to become zero? Give your answer as a positive number with (at least) 2 significant figures.

feedback.correct: Correct. You can read the coastline orientation that gives a zero transport from the plot or compute it by iteration using the provided cell.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Read the coastline orientation from the plot as well as compute it by iteration using the provided cell.
